INVESTIGATION:
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4157 (1) Behavior Management
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written policies and
Description procedures that describe the institution’s behavior management
system. The policies and procedures shall be reviewed annually and
2

updated as needed. These shall be available to all residents, their
families, and referring agencies.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 1/19/23, staff member picked up a vulnerable youth at the facility
and swung the youth in circles off an employee's back. Youth was
mocked for wearing a helmet. Staff member chased youth in the unit.
Investigation Interviews:
Staff 2/ Complaint Source was interviewed via phone on January
25, 2022, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 2 reported she
worked for the facility for one week and resigned on January 19, 2023.
The reason Staff 2 resigned on January 19, 2023, was due to the
concerns within the allegations and she stated she did not tell her
employer her concerns but rather stated the position was not a good fit
for her. Staff 2 reported on that day, Youth A was crying a lot and staff
were trying to encourage him to go to the dining room area for lunch.
She reported Staff 1 was sitting on the couch and Youth A joined him
on the couch. Staff 2 reported Youth A stood up and maneuvered his
way between Staff 1’s back and the backing of the couch. She stated
Youth A then put his arms around Staff 1’s neck and Staff 1 ended up
grabbing on to Youth A’s arms to stabilize him and stood up. She
reported Staff 1 spun in a circle with Youth A on his back and then he
set Youth A on the couch. She reported she was unsure why Staff 1
spun Youth A in a circle on his back. When asked did she think it was
to assist with getting Youth A off his back she reported she did not
know. Staff 2 reported she does not think Staff 1 did this to cause harm
to Youth A. She reported she has never seen another staff member do
this and this is her second time shadowing on this unit. Staff 2 reported
Youth A will hit his head against the walls at time and staff have to put a
helmet on him. She reported Staff 1 and Staff 3 were mocking Youth A
for a long period of time when he had his helmet on. When asked what
the mocking was she reported both Staff 1 and Staff 3 said to Youth A
“Hahaha now you cannot hit your head against the wall.” Staff 2
reported another concern was that Youth A will also run around the
living area flapping his arms and Staff 1 and Staff 3 just continued to
chase him around. She reported she does not remember if he had hit
his head or if his helmet was on during that time.
Youth A is non-verbal youth. This consultant viewed Youth A’s
interactions at the facility on January 24, 2023. Youth A was
spinning in circles around this consultant. Youth A appeared to be in
positive spirits and interacted with staff members on the unit. This
consultant viewed Youth A running up to Staff 1 and there were no
concerns.
4

Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on January 24,
2023, in collaboration with the MDHHS Worker. Staff 1 reported he
has worked at the facility for about 17 years. He reported he was
shocked by the allegations and that he would never do anything to
harm Youth A. Staff 1 reported on January 19, 2023, Supervisor 1, Staff
3 and Staff 4 were working the shift with him. He reported Staff 2 was
shadowing him but really kept to herself during the shift and played on
her phone. Staff 1 reported he never sung Youth A in a circle. He
reported he remembers he was sitting on the couch and Youth A got up
on the couch and stood behind Staff 1’s back. He reported Youth A
grabbed onto Staff 1’s neck and tried to claw his hands onto Staff 1’s
face. He reported he then held onto Youth A’s arms that were around
his neck to stabilize him and was able to move Youth A off his back
from picking him slightly up and placing him safety off his back. Staff 1
reported this is common for Youth A to do to staff. Staff 1 reported he
has never mocked Youth A for wearing a helmet and has never heard
anyone else mock Youth A for wearing a helmet. He reported Youth A
does not always wear his helmet on the unit. Staff 1 reported staff have
to put Youth A’s helmet on for safety when he begins to show signs, he
is about to head bang. Staff 1 reported when Youth A begins to run
more around the living area that is an indication that he may hit his
head, so staff are to follow him and put his helmet on. Staff 1 reported
this is a common occurrence and he will tell Youth A “safety first” before
putting his helmet on. He reported staff also will follow Youth A with a
safety pad so if Youth A tries to hit the front of his head staff can use
the pad to protect Youth A’s head. Staff 1 reported this is a part of
Youth A’s calming/safety plan. He reported those plans are all kept in
the staff office and staff are to review them. Staff 1 reported staff are to
always remain positive with the youth and never to go hands on with a
youth unless they are in danger to themself or others. Staff 1 reported
he does not have concerns of how staff treat Youth A and feel that staff
do a great job with Youth A’s care. He reported Youth A is on one-to-
one status, meaning one staff is responsible to supervise only Youth A
and staff will switch out as his one-to-one staff because Youth A can be
a lot to handle with being nonverbal and unpredictable.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
January 24, 2023, in collaboration with the MDHHS Worker.
Supervisor 2 reported she worked on January 19, 2023 with Staff 1.
She reported she did not see any concerns with the treatment of Youth
A from Staff 1. Supervisor 2 reported Youth A had his normal behaviors
on that day and staff were able to meet his needs. She reported Youth
A is a nonverbal autistic youth and can be easily frustrated. She
reported Youth A likes to spin in circles, will run around the living area
and is known for banging his head. Supervisor 2 reported when a staff
member is sitting on the couch Youth A will sometimes get behind the
4

staff’s back and latch on to them by grabbing onto their face or will
attempt to bite them. She reported this has happened to her that she
will make sure to stabilize Youth A’s arms and put him to the ground
safely, so no one gets hurts. She reported she never saw Staff 1 swing
Youth A in circles off his back. Supervisor 2 reported Youth A will show
signs he is about to head bang by running around more. Staff are to
follow him to get his helmet on for safety or follow him with the pad so
he doesn’t hurt his head. She reported she has never seen staff chase
after Youth A for no reason other than to make sure he was being safe.
Supervisor 2 reported she has also never heard staff, including Staff 1,
mock Youth A for wearing a helmet. Supervisor 2 reported staff are
aware of Youth A’s treatment and behavior needs by his safety/calming
plan and that is located within the staff office. Supervisor 2 reported she
has no concerns with the way Youth A was treated on January 19,
2023. She reported Staff 2 was a newer staff that was shadowing Staff
1 on that day. She reported Staff 2 was not engaged with the youth and
appeared uninterested. Supervisor 2 reported she had to redirect Staff
2 to make sure she was engaged within her training and not sitting on
her phone.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on January 26,
2023, in collaboration with the MDHHS Worker. Staff 3 reported she
worked on January 19, 2023 and was assigned as Youth A’s one-to-
one staff. She reported Youth A had no out of the ordinary behaviors.
She reported herself and Staff 1 had to put Youth A’s helmet on twice
that shift because he was attempting to hit his head. She reported they
never chased him around the unit but followed him to make sure he
was safe. Staff 3 reported herself and Staff 1 never mocked Youth A for
wearing a helmet or said to him “hahaha now you cannot hit your head
against the wall.” She reported she has never heard anyone mock
Youth A for wearing a helmet. Staff 3 reported she was present when
Youth A grabbed onto Staff 1’s back when on the couch. She reported
they were sitting on the couch and Youth A got between Staff 1’s back
and the back of the couch. Youth A then grabbed onto Staff 1’s neck.
She reported Staff 1 then made sure to safely secure Youth A’s hands
with his own hands and turned Youth A around. She reported Staff 1
physically moved Youth A off his back and moved him into a safe
standing position. Staff 3 reported Youth A did not get harmed by this
and was doing his happy dance once he was back on the ground. She
reported it looked like Youth A thought it was a game. Staff 3 reported
Staff 1 did not spin Youth A around on his back. She reported she has
no concerns with the treatment of Youth A. Staff 3 reported Youth A’s
behaviors can sometimes be overwhelming and that is why the switch
off for one-to-one staff. She reported his calming/safety plan is posted
in the staff office and she reads it every day before her shift.
4

Staff 4 was interviewed face to face at the facility on January 26,
2023, in collaboration with the MDHHS Worker. Staff 4 reported
Youth A can be handful at times but has made great progress since
being at the facility. He reported on January 19, 2023, he worked with
Staff 1, Staff 3, Supervisor 2 and Staff 2(who was completing a shadow
shift under Staff 1). He reported Youth A did not have any non-typical
behaviors during that shift. Staff 4 reported he does not remember of
any staff that day chasing Youth A around the facility and reported staff
do follow Youth A around because he is known to hit his head on the
ground or wall. He reported staff will have to put Youth A’s helmet on or
follow him with a pad to help keep his head safe. Staff 4 reported he did
not hear any staff mock Youth A for wearing a helmet on shift or any
other time. Staff 4 reported he did not see Staff 1 swing Youth A on his
back. He reported Youth A will sometimes sit on the couch next to a
staff. To express he wants a staff to get up he will try to wiggle his body
behind the staff’s back and the couch. Staff 4 reported he has had it
happen to him that Youth A got behind his back and put his arms and
body weight behind his back to get him to move. He reported in that
situation he had to wiggle his own body off the couch so that Youth A
would loosen his grip. Staff 4 reported he has no concerns with the
treatment Youth A receives at the facility and reported all the staff work
well with him. Staff 4 reported he did have concerns with Staff 2 while
she was doing her shadow shift and felt like she did not want to be
there. He reported Staff 2 sat on her phone for most of her shift, would
not engage with anyone and would not follow the redirects of
Supervisor 2 as it pertained to her level of engagement.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
January 24, 2023, in collaboration with the MDHHS Worker.
Supervisor 1 reported he supervises all the new staff members while
they are onboarding and training. He reported Staff 2 started the
beginning of January and appeared to be more overwhelmed with the
job requirements. Supervisor 1 reported on January 19, 2023, Staff 2
sent him a text message stating that she does not feel this job is the
right fit for her and quit that day. He reported she never brought up any
concerns about Staff 1 or the treatment of Youth A. Supervisor 1
reported he has no concerns with the treatment of Youth A at the facility
and no concerns have been reported to him.
Chief Administrator was interviewed face to face at the facility on
January 24, 2023, in collaboration with the MDHHS Worker. Chief
Administrator reported there has been no complaints made to her about
the care of Youth A. She reported there has also been no reported
concerns of Staff 1 interactions with Youth A or any other youth at the
facility.
4

Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on January 26,
2023, in collaboration with the MDHHS Worker. Youth B reported he
has lived at the facility for about four months and reported he feels safe
and likes the facility. He reported there are staff at the facility he feels
he can turn to when he needs to. When asked what his thoughts are of
Staff 1, he reported Staff 1 is a really good staff member. He reported
Staff 1 typically works with Youth A and does a good job at keeping
Youth A safe. Youth B reported he lives on the same side of the facility
as Youth A and Youth A is a non-verbal youth. He reported Youth A
sometimes has to wear a helmet because he will hit his head on the
wall. Youth B reported he was watched staff put Youth A’s helmet on
and denied ever hearing staff mock Youth A for wearing a helmet. He
reported he has never seen staff chase Youth A around. Youth B
reported he has never seen a staff member spin Youth A around in the
air on their back.
Conference call was held with MDHHS Worker on February 2,
2023. MDHHS worker reported there are no findings to their
investigation.
Documents Reviewed:
- Youth A’s facility file- A collection of the past three months incident
reports were gathered and showed Youth A has a history of self-injuring
and assaulting staff when upset.
- Youth A’s Individual Safety and Calming Plan dated November
14, 2022- This safety plan notes Youth A has the precursors to
aggression includes crying, whining, pulling, pushing or kicking staff.
Pro-active strategies staff can use is waiting out the behavior while
keeping him safe and blocking the aggression. Staff are to use Youth
A’s helmet and pad to block him from hitting his head on the wall and
floor.
- Facility Injury and Bruise Chart for Youth A- Bruise charting for
Youth A was reviewed for the dates of January 18, 2023 through
January 20, 2023. The bruise charting was documented on first,
second, and third shift each day. There was new bruising or marks
noted from the date of the incident occurring on January 19, 2023.
- Developmental Adolescent Residential Treatment Behavior
Management Policy- Positive interventions strategies should be used
by staff to help assist the youth develop improved problem solving, self-
management, and social skills.
- Developmental Adolescent Residential Treatment Restraint
Policy- Physical Management may only occur with a youth whose
behavior is significantly dangerous to self or others. Physical
Management is performed according to the current techniques of the
“Handle with Care”, DART’s approved crisis intervention program. The
use of force and duration of restraint must be limited to that which is
4

necessary to ensure the optimal care, welfare, safety, and security of
all. Restraint techniques must never be used for punishment, discipline,
or retaliation. Prohibited Behavior Management Techniques at the
facility includes corporal or physical punishment including spanking,
hitting, pinching, slapping, or hair pulling. Staff should not yell, threaten,
ridicule, or humiliate youth and those acts are strictly prohibited.
- HR file and Training Log for Staff 1- Staff 1 has only had one
disciplinary action noted within his HR file since being employed in the
facility for 17 years. This disciplinary action was in February of 2018
due to completing an unapproved restraint of a youth while a youth was
being unsafe within an agency vehicle. Staff 1 received extra support
for supervision and training due to this action. Staff 1 is all up to date on
required trainings.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance with following the behavior
management policy within the facility. Throughout the interviews staff
and youth denied that Staff 1 swung Youth A in circles off his back.
Also staff and youth denied staff mocking Youth A for wearing a helmet,
or chasing Youth A. Staff 1 rolled Youth A off his back, there was no
mocking of Youth A wearing a helmet, and do not chase Youth A. It
was found Staff 1 did have to move Youth A off his back due to Youth A
grabbing on to him and he was placing him off the couch to make sure
he was safe. Staff do follow Youth A to make sure he is safe from
banging his head on the wall as noted in his safety/calming plan.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract and policy. It is
recommended that the current license status be continued.
